repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Financial Sector Deepening and
            Intermediation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Several lessons are drawn
            from the project, lessons which further reinforce the need
            to balance realistic objectives, and coverage of the
            project, particularly, given the Bank leverage on the
            government of Pakistan is considered weak. Nonetheless, the
            demonstrated project ownership, and commitment were key
            during project preparation, and, helped a timely project
            restructuring reduce implementation delays, and costs.
            Project experience also shows the importance of the
            Bank's strong supervision and monitoring of the
            project's financial management, which included the
            guidance provided by project accounting staff, ensuring that
            weak financial management areas be addressed, and timely
            improved. While policy changes usually take time, requiring
            completed implementation of reforms, in the process,
            governments and finance institutions should promote
            development of alternative mechanisms, by facilitating the
            development of markets through better information, better
            contract dispute resolution, and similar market supportive infrastructure.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Financial Sector Deepening and
            Intermediation Project (FSDIP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Deepening and
            Intermediation Project will continue and expand the reform
            process started under the Financial Sector Adjustment Loan
            and support the Government of Pakistan's strategy for
            macroeconomic and financial sector reforms, focusing on:
            assisting the private sector to respond to the changing
            economic environment by providing non-subsidizing resources
            for investments and helping to deepen the financial system,
            promote new financial instruments and strengthen the State
            Bank of Pakistan (SBP) and other financial institutions
            (FIs). The project will consist of: a) a line of credit
            through the Administrative Unit (AU) to eligible banking and
            non-bank financial institutions for on-lending to private
            enterprises requiring term finance for all economic
            activities except real estate, trading and certain consumer
            services; and b) technical training to: 1) the SBP for the
            enhancement of its regulatory functions and improvement of
            its operational systems; 2) the Corporate Law Authority and
            Controller of Insurance for institutional building; 3)
            Bankers Equity Limited for the establishment of an AU,
            implementation of various studies and enforcement of
            environmental standards; and 4) the Privatization Commission
            for the preparation of a number of FIs for privatization
            and/or restructuring and valuation of State Life Insurance Corporation.
